newsitem.title: FRANCE: Beaujolais Nouveau rebounds after nuclear boycott.
newsitem.headline: Beaujolais Nouveau rebounds after nuclear boycott.

text.p: Beaujolais Nouveau, the heavily hyped young wine hit hard last year by a boycott over French nuclear testing, is set to make a comeback when it goes on sale after midnight on Wednesday, wine industry officials said.
"Happily, the boycott is over," said Bernard Georges, export manager for the Duboeuf winery, France's largest exporter of the world-famous wine.
"Beaujolais is not dead. Our export volumes are up, and this year's new wine is remarkable," Georges told Reuters.
The new wine, harvested just two months ago, goes on sale just after midnight on Wednesday in what has become an annual rite in major cities around the globe.

Bottles of the new wine have already been shipped via jet, rail and lorry around the world, with the understanding that it cannot be uncorked until seconds after midnight -- the traditional third Thursday of the month.

Some wine industry figures had predicted last year's boycott would do irreparable damage to Beaujolais. They said consumers would turn permanently to new wines of similar -- or better -- quality from Australia, Chili and California.
It looked like the end of the heady days of yore, when yuppies in Tokyo and New York would pay up to $20 a glass.

But exporters said the Beaujolais myth has, if anything, spread even further this year, with bottles shipped to such far-flung destinations as Damascus, Hanoi, the Fiji Islands, Cuba and Maputo in Mozambique.
France's final series of six nuclear tests, which triggered international outrage before ending in January, had cut deeply into last year's sales of Beaujolais Nouveau.
Eighteen percent less of the trendy young wine was sold during the 1995 campaign compared to the previous year, said the National Interprofessional Wine Office (ONIVINS).
Sales in Japan and the Nordic countries were hit hardest by consumer boycotts while U.S. sales were also down, industry officials said.
This year, however, feedback from forwarders suggested an increase in demand from North America while the Japanese market was showing signs of recovery, the Beaujolais Wine Board said.
"Exports to Japan are doing extremely well this year," confirmed Duboeuf's Georges.
Ironically, the 1996 vintage had been virtually written off in late August after heavy rains threatened to bring on a bad outbreak of rot in the Beaujolais region.
But two weeks of cool sunshine in early September saved the crop, earning it the nickname "the miracle vintage."
Beajolais Wine Board experts who have sampled it have high praise for its "refreshing and lively taste" and "nose of red berries."
